Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Expansive Meanings and Makings in ArtScience

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Expansive Meanings and Makings in ArtScience will design and develop an innovative model of ArtScience learning for middle and high school age youth from communities underrepresented in STEM fields. ArtScience is an emerging movement emphasizing commonalities in thinking practices used by artists and scientists as they explore complex 21st century problems. Youth will engage in ArtScience inquiries in two scientific domains of significance to them and their communities: climate change and the human microbiome. The project investigates the hypothesis that an ArtScience approach will expand opportunities for historically underrepresented youth to develop meaningful understanding of core ideas related to Earth?s systems, ecosystems and microbiology as well as increased fluency with scientific and artistic practices related to the interpretation, production, and use of complex scientific visualizations. Design and research activities will be carried out collaboratively in informal and formal learning environments: in Seattle with a youth theatre company, Red Eagle Soaring, that serves primarily Native youth, and in Boston with a public high school, Boston Arts Academy, that serves youth from underrepresented communities. A multidisciplinary team of learning scientists, scientists, and artists will collaborate in the research, including: the Ch√®che Konnen Center at TERC, University of Washington, Broad Institute, and locally-based artists.

In Seattle and Boston, youth will learn to interpret and investigate scientific visualizations from open access data exchanges. To help students connect with the larger, more complex visualizations, they will construct their own data on a smaller scale. Guided by participating scientists, artists and teachers, youth will learn to develop creative responses to the visualizations in ways that integrate scientific and artistic ideas, practices, materials, and concerns. This design-based research project will a) design and progressively refine an ArtScience model, b) document and analyze youths? engagement with ArtScience practices and their articulation with scientific practices, and c) assess growth in youths? conceptual understanding, fluency in use of scientific and artistic practices, and emerging identity relationships to science. A total of 100 youth will participate, 50 in each of two design cycles. Data sources will include videotapes of implementation sessions at each site, session log records, youth-generated artifacts, pre- and post-clinical interviews, and academic performance and attendance records. Data will be analyzed using interaction analysis, descriptive data analysis, discourse analysis, and life story and cognitive narratological approaches. Analyses will be coordinated across sites using shared, secure database and analysis software.

This research will establish an empirical foundation in ArtScience learning that articulates with the new science frameworks and mobilizes the intellectual and creative potential of youth from communities historically underrepresented in STEM fields. Major outcomes will include an evidence-based model of ArtScience learning and evidence-based design principles that can guide adaptation of the model in formal and informal settings serving underrepresented youth. The model, design principles, assessment results, and examples of ArtScience inquiries will be shared widely through professional and community networks, locally, nationally and internationally. Through these efforts the project addresses both the STEM learning environments and broadening participation of the EHR Core program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Expansive Meanings and Makings in ArtScience project built on commonalities in creative practices used by artists and scientists to design engaging learning experiences for youth from communities historically marginalized in science.  Researchers, teachers, artists, scientists, and community members collaboratively designed learning experiences that focused on exploring and understanding relations between nature and culture as respectful, reciprocal, and responsible in ways consonant with contemporary ecological science. The ecological domain of study was the emerging science of the human microbiome, which speaks to the importance of creating just, thriving, and sustainable ways of living responsive to 21st century challenges. 

In a public high school, youth engaged in artscience inquiries into the human microbiome, a field of science that is characterizing the microbial communities that live in and on the human body and studying their role in human health and disease.  Working with practicing artists and scientists over four weeks, youth cultivated the microbial communities living on the palms and fingers of their hands. They explored microbial-human relationships through a variety of artistic and scientific practices. With a choreographer, they created movement phrases to animate and embody microbial scale; with a sculptor, they created three-dimensional worlds of microbial-human interactions; with a violist, they musically scored growth as it unfolded in cultures of the microbial communities on their hands; with a painter, they created visual expressions of microbe-human relationships; with a filmmaker, they scripted microbe-human relations in the film noir genre; with scientists, they explored contemporary studies, emerging findings, and open questions in human microbiome research.  As a culminating project, youth created their own responses to the human microbiome. They drew from visual art, instrumental and vocal music, spoken word, video, dance, body art, theatre, and sculpture to explore ideas, feelings, and perspectives related to the human microbiome that had become interesting to them and that they felt were important to communicate to their families and communities.  

In their expressive responses and in interviews, there was strong evidence in support of artscience learning.  Youth

  • came to understand microbe-human relations through an ecological lens as interdependent, a shift from their earlier general view of microbes as bad or hostile to human well-being
  • expressed a growing awareness and concern about societal misunderstandings of microbial-human relations and their implications for health and well-being
  • came to understood art and science as deeply connected creative disciplines, a shift from their earlier view of art and science as distinct, with art subordinate to science
  • characterized artscience as supporting creative, expansive, emotionally, and ethically engaged learning in contrast to traditional science education from which they routinely disengaged

These findings make a strong case for the power of artscience learning to foster youths' understanding and appreciation of complex ecological science critical to 21st century ways of living; cultivate their creative, analytic, and communicative repertoires; and transform high school science into a creative, interdisciplinary, and socially meaningful experience that engages young people intellectually, emotionally, aesthetically, and ethically with issues critical to their present and future lives.
